Ditto: Fair and Robust Federated Learning Through Personalization

Tian Li â€ƒâ€ƒ Shengyuan Hu â€ƒâ€ƒ Ahmad Beirami â€ƒâ€ƒ Virginia Smith
Abstract

Fairness and robustness are two important concerns for federated learning systems. In this work, we identify that robustness to data and model poisoning attacks and fairness, measured as the uniformity of performance across devices, are competing constraints in statistically heterogeneous networks. To address these constraints, we propose employing a simple, general framework for personalized federated learning, Ditto, that can inherently provide fairness and robustness benefits, and develop a scalable solver for it. Theoretically, we analyze the ability of Ditto to achieve fairness and robustness simultaneously on a class of linear problems. Empirically, across a suite of federated datasets, we show that Ditto not only achieves competitive performance relative to recent personalization methods, but also enables more accurate, robust, and fair models relative to state-of-the-art fair or robust baselines.

1 Introduction

Federated learning (FL) aims to collaboratively learn from data that has been generated by, and resides on, a number of remote devices or serversÂ (McMahan etÂ al., 2017). FL stands to produce highly accurate statistical models by aggregating knowledge from disparate data sources. However, to deploy FL in practice, it is necessary for the resulting systems to be not only accurate, but to also satisfy a number of pragmatic constraints regarding issues such as fairness, robustness, and privacy. Simultaneously satisfying these varied constraints can be exceptionally difficultÂ (Kairouz etÂ al., 2019).

We focus in this work specifically on issues of accuracy, fairness (i.e., limiting performance disparities across the networkÂ (Mohri etÂ al., 2019)), and robustness (against training-time data and model poisoning attacks). Many prior efforts have separately considered fairness or robustness in federated learning. For instance, fairness strategies include using minimax optimization to focus on the worst-performing devicesÂ (Mohri etÂ al., 2019; Hu etÂ al., 2020) or reweighting the devices to allow for a flexible fairness/accuracy tradeoffÂ (Li etÂ al., 2020e, 2021). Robust methods commonly use techniques such as gradient clippingÂ (Sun etÂ al., 2019) or robust aggregationÂ (Blanchard etÂ al., 2017; Yin etÂ al., 2018).

While these approaches may be effective at either promoting fairness or defending against training-time attacks in isolation, we show that the constraints of fairness and robustness can directly compete with one another when training a single global model, and that simultaneously optimizing for accuracy, fairness, and robustness requires careful consideration. For example, as we empirically demonstrate (SectionÂ 4), current fairness approaches can render FL systems highly susceptible to training time attacks from malicious devices. On the other hand, robust methods may filter out rare but informative updates, causing unfairnessÂ (Wang etÂ al., 2020).

In this work, we investigate a simple, scalable technique to simultaneously improve accuracy, fairness, and robustness in federated learning. While addressing the competing constraints of FL may seem like an insurmountable problem, we identify that statistical heterogeneity (i.e., non-identically distributed data) is a root cause for tension between these constraints, and is key in paving a path forward. In particular, we suggest that methods for personalized FLâ€”which model and adapt to the heterogeneity in federated settings by learning distinct models for each deviceâ€”may provide inherent benefits in terms of fairness and robustness.

To explore this idea, we propose Ditto, a scalable federated multi-task learning framework. Ditto can be seen as a lightweight personalization add-on for standard global FL. It is applicable to both convex and non-convex objectives, and inherits similar privacy and efficiency properties as traditional FL. We evaluate Ditto on a suite of federated benchmarks and show that, surprisingly, this simple form of personalization can in fact deliver better accuracy, robustness, and fairness benefits than state-of-the-art, problem-specific objectives that consider these constraints separately. We summarize our contributions below:

  • â€¢

    We propose Ditto, a multi-task learning objective for federated learning that provides personalization while retaining similar efficiency and privacy benefits as traditional FL. We provide convergence guarantees for our proposed Ditto solver, which incorporate common practices in cross-device federated learning such as limited device participation and local updating. Despite its simplicity, we show that Ditto can deliver similar or superior accuracy relative to other common methods for personalized federated learning.

  • â€¢

    Next, we demonstrate that the benefits of Ditto go beyond accuracyâ€”showing that the personalized objective can inherently offer robustness superior to that of common robust FL methods across a diverse set of data and model poisoning attacks. On average across all datasets and attacks, Ditto improves test accuracy by âˆ¼similar-to\sim6% (absolute) over the strongest robust baseline.

  • â€¢

    Similarly, we show that Ditto can naturally increase fairnessâ€”reducing variance of the test accuracy across devices by âˆ¼similar-to\sim10% while maintaining similar or superior accuracy relative to state-of-the-art methods for fair FL.

  • â€¢

    Finally, we highlight that Ditto is particularly useful for practical applications where we simultaneously care about multiple constraints (accuracy, fairness, and robustness). We motivate this through analysis on a toy example in SectionÂ 3, as well as experiments across a suite of federated datasets in SectionÂ 4.

2 Background & Related Work

Robustness and fairness are two broad areas of research that extend well beyond the application of federated learning. In this section we provide precise definitions of the notions of robustness/fairness considered in this work, and give an overview of prior work in robustness, fairness, and personalization in the context of federated learning.

Robustness in Federated Learning.

Training-time attacks (including data poisoning and model poisoning) have been extensively studied in prior workÂ (Biggio etÂ al., 2012; Gu etÂ al., 2017; Chen etÂ al., 2017; Shafahi etÂ al., 2018; Liu etÂ al., 2018; Huang etÂ al., 2020; Xie etÂ al., 2020; Wang etÂ al., 2020; Dumford & Scheirer, 2018; Huang etÂ al., 2020). In federated settings, a number of strong attack methods have been explored, including scaling malicious model updatesÂ (Bagdasaryan etÂ al., 2020), collaborative attackingÂ (Sun etÂ al., 2020), defense-aware attacksÂ (Bhagoji etÂ al., 2019; Fang etÂ al., 2020), and adding edge-case adversarial training samplesÂ (Wang etÂ al., 2020). Our work aims to investigate common attacks related to Byzantine robustnessÂ (Lamport etÂ al., 2019), as formally described below.

Definition 1 (Robustness).

We are conceptually interested in Byzantine robustnessÂ (Lamport etÂ al., 2019), where the malicious devices can send arbitrary updates to the server to compromise training. To measure robustness, we assess the mean test performance on benign devices, i.e., we consider model w1subscriptğ‘¤1w_{1} to be more robust than w2subscriptğ‘¤2w_{2} to a specific attack if the mean test performance across the benign devices is higher for model w1subscriptğ‘¤1w_{1} than w2subscriptğ‘¤2w_{2} after training with the attack. We examine three widely-used attacks in our threat model:

  • â€¢

    (A1) Label poisoning: Corrupted devices do not have access to the training APIs and training samples are poisoned with flipped (if binary) or uniformly random noisy labelsÂ (Bhagoji etÂ al., 2019; Biggio etÂ al., 2011).

  • â€¢

    (A2) Random updates: Malicious devices send random zero-mean Gaussian parametersÂ (Xu & Lyu, 2020).

  • â€¢

    (A3) Model replacement: Malicious devices scale their adversarial updates to make them dominate the aggregate updatesÂ (Bagdasaryan etÂ al., 2020).

While non-exhaustive, these attacks have been commonly studied in distributed and federated settings, and explore corruption at various points (the underlying data, labels, or model). In terms of defenses, robust aggregation is a common strategy to mitigate the effect of malicious updatesÂ (Blanchard etÂ al., 2017; Pillutla etÂ al., 2019; Sun etÂ al., 2019; Li etÂ al., 2019; He etÂ al., 2020). Other defenses include gradient clippingÂ (Sun etÂ al., 2019) or normalizationÂ (Hu etÂ al., 2020). While these strategies can improve robustness, they may also produce unfair models by filtering out informative updates, especially in heterogeneous settingsÂ (Wang etÂ al., 2020). In our experiments (SectionÂ 4), we compare Ditto with several strong defenses (median, gradient clippingÂ (Sun etÂ al., 2019), Krum, Multi-KrumÂ (Blanchard etÂ al., 2017), gradient-norm based anomaly detectorÂ (Bagdasaryan etÂ al., 2020), and a new defense proposed herein) and show that Ditto can improve both robustness and fairness compared with these methods.

Fairness in Federated Learning.

Due to the heterogeneity of the data in federated networks, it is possible that the performance of a model will vary significantly across the devices. This concern, also known as representation disparityÂ (Hashimoto etÂ al., 2018), is a major challenge in FL, as it can potentially result in uneven outcomes for the devices. FollowingÂ Li etÂ al. (2020e), we provide a more formal definition of this fairness in the context of FL below:

Definition 2 (Fairness).

We say that a model w1subscriptğ‘¤1w_{1} is more fair than w2subscriptğ‘¤2w_{2} if the test performance distribution of w1subscriptğ‘¤1w_{1} across the network is more uniform than that of w2subscriptğ‘¤2w_{2}, i.e., stdâ€‹{Fkâ€‹(w1)}kâˆˆ[K]<stdâ€‹{Fkâ€‹(w2)}kâˆˆ[K]stdsubscriptsubscriptğ¹ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘¤1ğ‘˜delimited-[]ğ¾stdsubscriptsubscriptğ¹ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘¤2ğ‘˜delimited-[]ğ¾\textup{std}\left\{F_{k}(w_{1})\right\}_{k\in[K]}<\textup{std}\left\{F_{k}(w_{2})\right\}_{k\in[K]} where Fkâ€‹(â‹…)subscriptğ¹ğ‘˜â‹…F_{k}(\cdot) denotes the test loss on device kğ‘˜kâˆˆ\in[K]delimited-[]ğ¾[K], and stdâ€‹{â‹…}stdâ‹…\textup{std}\{\cdot\} denotes the standard deviation. In the presence of adversaries, we measure fairness only on benign devices.

We note that there exists a tension between variance and utility in the definition above; in general, a common goal is to lower the variance while maintaining a reasonable average performance (e.g., average test accuracy). To address representation disparity, it is common to use minimax optimizationÂ (Mohri etÂ al., 2019; Deng etÂ al., 2020) or flexible sample reweighting approachesÂ (Li etÂ al., 2020e, 2021) to encourage a more uniform quality of service. In all cases, by up-weighting the importance of rare devices or data, fair methods may not be robust in that they can easily overfit to corrupted devices (see SectionÂ 4.3). The tension between fairness and robustness has been studied in previous works, though for different notions of fairness (equalized odds) or robustness (backdoor attacks)Â (Wang etÂ al., 2020), or in centralized settingsÂ (Chang etÂ al., 2020). Recently,Â Hu etÂ al. (2020) proposed FedMGDA+, a method targeting fair and robust FL; however, this work combines classical fairness (minimax optimization) and robustness (gradient normalization) techniques, in contrast to the multi-task framework proposed herein, which we show can inherently provide benefits with respect to both constraints simultaneously.

Personalized Federated Learning.

Given the variability of data in federated networks, personalization is a natural approach used to improve accuracy. Numerous works have proposed techniques for personalized federated learning. Smith etÂ al. (2017) first explore personalized FL via a primal-dual MTL framework, which applies to convex settings. Personalized FL has also been explored through clusteringÂ (e.g., Ghosh etÂ al., 2020; Sattler etÂ al., 2020; Muhammad etÂ al., 2020), finetuning/transfer learningÂ (Zhao etÂ al., 2018; Yu etÂ al., 2020), meta-learningÂ (Jiang etÂ al., 2019; Chen etÂ al., 2018; Khodak etÂ al., 2019; Fallah etÂ al., 2020; Li etÂ al., 2020a; Singhal etÂ al., 2021), and other forms of MTL, such as hard model parameter sharingÂ (Agarwal etÂ al., 2020; Liang etÂ al., 2020) or the weighted combination method inÂ Zhang etÂ al. (2021). Our work differs from these approaches by simultaneously learning local and global models via a global-regularized MTL framework, which applies to non-convex ML objectives.

Similar in spirit to our approach are works that interpolate between global and local modelsÂ (Mansour etÂ al., 2020; Deng etÂ al., 2021). However, as discussed inÂ Deng etÂ al. (2021), these approaches can effectively reduce to local minimizers without additional constraints. The most closely related works are those that regularize personalized models towards their averageÂ (Hanzely & RichtÃ¡rik, 2020; Hanzely etÂ al., 2020; Dinh etÂ al., 2020), which can be seen as a form of classical mean-regularized MTLÂ (Evgeniou & Pontil, 2004). Our objective is similarly inspired by mean-regularized MTL, although we regularize towards a global model rather than the average personalized model. As we discuss in SectionÂ 3, one advantage of this is that it allows for methods designed for the global federated learning problem (e.g., optimization methods, privacy/security mechanisms) to be easily re-used in our framework, with the benefit of additional personalization. We compare against a range of personalized methods empirically in SectionÂ 4.4, showing that Ditto achieves similar or superior performance across a number of common FL benchmarks.

Finally, a key contribution of our work is jointly exploring the robustness and fairness benefits of personalized FL. The benefits of personalization for fairness alone have been demonstrated empirically in prior workÂ (Wang etÂ al., 2019; Hao etÂ al., 2020). Connections between personalization and robustness have also been explored inÂ Yu etÂ al. (2020), although the authors propose using personalization methods on top of robust mechanisms. Our work differs from these works by arguing that MTL itself offers inherent robustness and fairness benefits, and exploring the challenges that exist when attempting to satisfy both constraints simultaneously.

3 Ditto: Global-Regularized Federated Multi-Task Learning

In order to explore the possible fairness/robustness benefits of personalized FL, we first propose a simple and scalable framework for federated multi-task learning. As we will see, this lightweight personalization framework is amenable to analyses while also having strong empirical performance. We explain our proposed objective, Ditto, in SectionÂ 3.1 and then present a scalable algorithm to solve it in federated settings (SectionÂ 3.2). We provide convergence guarantees for our solver, and explain several practical benefits of our modular approach in terms of privacy and efficiency. Finally, in SectionÂ 3.3, we characterize the benefits of Ditto in terms of fairness and robustness on a class of linear problems. We empirically explore the fairness and robustness properties against state-of-the-art baselines in SectionÂ 4.

3.1 Ditto Objective

Traditionally, federated learning objectives consider fitting a single global model, wğ‘¤w, across all local data in the network. The aim is to solve:

Here the hyperparameter Î»ğœ†\lambda controls the interpolation between local and global models. When Î»ğœ†\lambda is set to 0, Ditto is reduced to training local models; as Î»ğœ†\lambda grows large, it recovers global model objective (Global Obj) (Î»â†’+âˆâ†’ğœ†\lambda\to+\infty).

Intuition for Fairness/Robustness Benefits.

In addition to improving accuracy via personalization, we argue that Ditto can offer fairness and robustness benefits. To reason about this, consider a simple case where data are homogeneous across devices. Without adversaries, learning a single global model is optimal for generalization. However, in the presence of adversaries, learning globally might introduce corruption, while learning local models may not generalize well due to limited sample size. Ditto with an appropriate value of Î»ğœ†\lambda offers a tradeoff between these two extremes: the smaller Î»ğœ†\lambda, the more the personalized models vksubscriptğ‘£ğ‘˜v_{k} can deviate from the (corrupted) global model wğ‘¤w, potentially providing robustness at the expense of generalization. In the heterogeneous case (which can lead to issues of unfairness as described in SectionÂ 2), a finite Î»ğœ†\lambda exists to offer robustness and fairness jointly. We explore these ideas more rigorously in SectionÂ 3.3 by analyzing the tradeoffs between accuracy, fairness, and robustness in terms of Î»ğœ†\lambda for a class of linear regression problems, and demonstrate fairness/robustness benefits of Ditto empirically in SectionÂ 4.

Other Personalization Schemes.

As discussed in SectionÂ 2, personalization is a widely-studied topic in FL. Our intuition in Ditto is that personalization, by reducing reliance on the global model, can reduce representation disparity (i.e., unfairness) and potentially improve robustness. It is possible that other personalization techniques beyond Ditto offer similar benefits: We provide some initial, encouraging results on this in SectionÂ 4.4. However, we specifically explore Ditto due to its simple nature, scalability, and strong empirical performance. Ditto is closely related to works that regularize personalized models towards their averageÂ (Hanzely & RichtÃ¡rik, 2020; Hanzely etÂ al., 2020; Dinh etÂ al., 2020), similar to classical mean-regularized MTLÂ (Evgeniou & Pontil, 2004); Ditto differs by regularizing towards a global model rather than the average personalized model. We find that this provides benefits in terms of analysis (SectionÂ 3.3), as we can easily reason about Ditto relative to the global (Î»â†’âˆâ†’ğœ†\lambda\to\infty) vs. local (Î»â†’0â†’ğœ†0\lambda\to 0) baselines; empirically, in terms of accuracy, fairness, and robustness (SectionÂ 4); and practically, in terms of the modularity it affords our corresponding solver (SectionÂ 3.2).

Other Regularizers.

To encourage the personalized models vksubscriptğ‘£ğ‘˜v_{k} to be close to the optimal global model wâˆ—superscriptğ‘¤w^{*}, there are choices beyond the L2subscriptğ¿2L_{2} norm that could be considered, e.g., using a Bregman divergence-based regularizer or reshaping the L2subscriptğ¿2L_{2} ball using the Fisher information matrix. Under the logistic loss (used in our experiments), the Bregman divergence will reduce to KL divergence, and its second-order Taylor expansion will result in an L2subscriptğ¿2L_{2} ball reshaped with the Fisher information matrix. Such regularizers are studied in other related contexts like continual learningÂ (Kirkpatrick etÂ al., 2017; Schwarz etÂ al., 2018), multi-task learningÂ (Yu etÂ al., 2020), or finetuning for language modelsÂ (Jiang etÂ al., 2020). However, in our experiments (SectionÂ 4.4), we find that incorporating approximate empirical Fisher informationÂ (Yu etÂ al., 2020; Kirkpatrick etÂ al., 2017) or symmetrized KL divergenceÂ (Jiang etÂ al., 2020) does not improve the performance over the simple L2subscriptğ¿2L_{2} regularized objective, while adding non-trivial computational overhead.

Remark (Relation to FedProx).

We note that the L2subscriptğ¿2L_{2} term in Ditto bears resemblance to FedProx, a method which was developed to address heterogeneity in federated optimizationÂ (Li etÂ al., 2020d). However, Ditto fundamentally differs from FedProx in that the goal is to learn personalized models vksubscriptğ‘£ğ‘˜v_{k}, while FedProx produces a single global model wğ‘¤w. For instance, when the regularization hyperparameter is zero, Ditto reduces to learning separate local models, whereas FedProx would reduce to FedAvg. In fact, Ditto is significantly more general than FedProx in that FedProx could be used as the global model solver in Ditto to optimize Gâ€‹(â‹…)ğºâ‹…G(\cdot). As discussed above, other regularizers beyond the L2subscriptğ¿2L_{2} norm may also be used in practice.

3.2 Ditto Solver

To solveÂ Ditto, we propose jointly solving for the global model wâˆ—superscriptğ‘¤w^{*} and personalized models {vk}kâˆˆ[K]subscriptsubscriptğ‘£ğ‘˜ğ‘˜delimited-[]ğ¾\{v_{k}\}_{k\in[K]} in an alternating fashion, as summarized in AlgorithmÂ 1. Optimization proceeds in two phases: (i) updates to the global model, wâˆ—superscriptğ‘¤w^{*}, are computed across the network, and then (ii) the personalized models vksubscriptğ‘£ğ‘˜v_{k} are fit on each local device. The process of optimizing wâˆ—superscriptğ‘¤w^{*} is exactly the same as optimizing for any objective Gâ€‹(â‹…)ğºâ‹…G(\cdot) in federated settings: If we use iterative solvers, then at each communication round, each selected device can solve the local subproblem of Gâ€‹(â‹…)ğºâ‹…G(\cdot) approximately (Line 5). For personalization, device kğ‘˜k solves the global-regularized local objective minvkâ¡hkâ€‹(vk;wt)subscriptsubscriptğ‘£ğ‘˜subscriptâ„ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘£ğ‘˜superscriptğ‘¤ğ‘¡\min_{v_{k}}h_{k}(v_{k};w^{t}) inexactly at each round (Line 6). Due to this alternating scheme, our solver can scale well to large networks, as it does not introduce additional communication or privacy overheads compared with existing solvers for Gâ€‹(â‹…)ğºâ‹…G(\cdot). In our experiments (all except TableÂ 3), we use FedAvg as the objective and solver for Gâ€‹(â‹…)ğºâ‹…G(\cdot), under which we simply let device kğ‘˜k run local SGD on Fksubscriptğ¹ğ‘˜F_{k} (Line 5). We provide a simplified algorithm definition using FedAvg for the wâˆ—superscriptğ‘¤w^{*} update in AlgorithmÂ 2 in the appendix.

We note that another natural choice to solve the Ditto objective is to first obtain wâˆ—superscriptğ‘¤w^{*}, and then for each device kğ‘˜k, perform finetuning on the local objective minvkâ¡hkâ€‹(vk;wâˆ—)subscriptsubscriptğ‘£ğ‘˜subscriptâ„ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘£ğ‘˜superscriptğ‘¤\min_{v_{k}}h_{k}(v_{k};w^{*}). These two approaches will arrive at the same solutions in strongly convex cases. In non-convex settings, we observe that there may be additional benefits of joint optimization: Empirically, we find that the updating scheme tends to guide the optimization trajectory towards a better solution compared with finetuning starting from wâˆ—superscriptğ‘¤w^{*}, particularly when wâˆ—superscriptğ‘¤w^{*} is corrupted by adversarial attacks (SectionÂ 4.4). Intuitively, under training-time attacks, the global model may start from a random one, get optimized, and gradually become corrupted as training proceedsÂ (Li etÂ al., 2020b). In these cases, feeding in early global information (i.e., before the global model converges to wâˆ—superscriptğ‘¤w^{*}) may be helpful under strong attacks.

We note that Ditto with joint optimization requires the devices to maintain local states (i.e., personalized models) and carry these local states to the next communication round where they are selected. Solving Ditto with finetuning does not need devices to be stateful, while losing the benefits of alternate updating discussed above.

Modularity of Ditto.

From the Ditto objective and AlgÂ 1, we see that a key advantage of Ditto is its modularity, i.e., that we can readily use prior art developed for the Global Obj along with the personalization add-on of hkâ€‹(vk;wâˆ—)subscriptâ„ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘£ğ‘˜superscriptğ‘¤h_{k}(v_{k};w^{*}), as highlighted in red. This has several benefits:

  • â€¢

    Optimization: It is possible to plug in other methods beyond FedAvgÂ (e.g., Li etÂ al., 2020c; Karimireddy etÂ al., 2020; Reddi etÂ al., 2021) in AlgorithmÂ 1 to update the global model, and inherit the convergence benefits, if any (we make this more precise in TheoremÂ 1).

  • â€¢

    Privacy: Ditto communicates the same information over the network as typical FL solvers for the global objective, thus preserving whatever privacy or communication benefits exist for the global objective and its respective solver. This is different from most other personalization methods where global model updates depend on local parameters, which may raise privacy concernsÂ (London, 2020).

  • â€¢

    Robustness: Beyond the inherent robustness benefits of personalization, robust global methods can be used with Ditto to further improve performance (see SectionÂ 4.4).

In particular, while not the main focus of our work, we note that Ditto may offer a better privacy-utility tradeoff than training a global model. For instance, when training Ditto, if we fix the number of communication rounds and add the same amount of noise per round to satisfy differential privacy, Ditto consumes exactly the same privacy budget as normal global training, while yielding higher accuracy via personalization (SectionÂ 4). Similar benefits have been studied, e.g., via finetuning strategiesÂ (Yu etÂ al., 2020).

Convergence of AlgorithmÂ 1.

Note that optimizing the global model wtsuperscriptğ‘¤ğ‘¡w^{t} does not depend on any personalized models {vk}kâˆˆ[K]subscriptsubscriptğ‘£ğ‘˜ğ‘˜delimited-[]ğ¾\{v_{k}\}_{k\in[K]}. Therefore, wğ‘¤w enjoys the same global convergence rates with the solver we use for GğºG. Under this observation, we present the local convergence of AlgorithmÂ 1.

Theorem 1 (Local Convergence of Alg.Â 1; formal statement and proof in TheoremÂ 10).

Assume for kâˆˆ[K]ğ‘˜delimited-[]ğ¾k\in[K], Fksubscriptğ¹ğ‘˜F_{k} is strongly convex and smooth, under common assumptions, if wtsuperscriptğ‘¤ğ‘¡w^{t} converges to wâˆ—superscriptğ‘¤w^{*} with rate gâ€‹(t)ğ‘”ğ‘¡g(t), then there exists a constant Cğ¶C<<âˆ\infty such that for Î»âˆˆâ„,ğœ†â„\lambda\in\mathbb{R}, and for kâˆˆ[K]ğ‘˜delimited-[]ğ¾k\in[K], vktsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘£ğ‘˜ğ‘¡v_{k}^{t} converges to vkâˆ—:=argâ€‹minvkâ¡hkâ€‹(vk;wâˆ—)assignsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘£ğ‘˜subscriptargminsubscriptğ‘£ğ‘˜subscriptâ„ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘£ğ‘˜superscriptğ‘¤v_{k}^{*}:=\operatorname*{arg\,min}_{v_{k}}h_{k}(v_{k};w^{*}) with rate Câ€‹gâ€‹(t)ğ¶ğ‘”ğ‘¡Cg(t).

Using TheoremÂ 1, we can directly plug in previous convergence analyses for any Gâ€‹(â‹…)ğºâ‹…G(\cdot). For instance, when the global objective and its solver are those of FedAvg, we can obtain an Oâ€‹(1/t)ğ‘‚1ğ‘¡O(1/t) convergence rate for Ditto under suitable conditions (CorollaryÂ 1). We provide a full theorem statement and proof of convergence in AppendixÂ B.

3.3 Analyzing the Fairness/Robustness Benefits of Ditto in Simplified Settings

In this section, we more rigorously explore the fairness/robustness benefits of Ditto on a class of linear problems. Throughout our analysis, we assume Gâ€‹(â‹…)ğºâ‹…G(\cdot) is the standard objective in FedAvgÂ (McMahan etÂ al., 2017).

Point Estimation.

To provide intuition, we first examine a toy one-dimensional point estimation problem. Denote the underlying models for the devices as {vk}kâˆˆ[K]subscriptsubscriptğ‘£ğ‘˜ğ‘˜delimited-[]ğ¾\{v_{k}\}_{k\in[K]}, vkâˆˆâ„subscriptğ‘£ğ‘˜â„v_{k}\in\mathbb{R}, and let the points on device kğ‘˜k, {xk,1,â€¦,xk,n}subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜1â€¦subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜ğ‘›\{x_{k,1},\dots,x_{k,n}\}111For ease of notation, we assume each device has the same number of training samples. It is straightforward to extend the current analysis to allow for varying number of samples per device., be observations of vksubscriptğ‘£ğ‘˜v_{k} with random perturbation, i.e., xk,i=vk+zk,isubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜ğ‘–subscriptğ‘£ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘§ğ‘˜ğ‘–x_{k,i}=v_{k}+z_{k,i}, where zk,iâˆ¼ğ’©â€‹(0,Ïƒ2)similar-tosubscriptğ‘§ğ‘˜ğ‘–ğ’©0superscriptğœ2z_{k,i}\sim\mathcal{N}(0,\sigma^{2}) and are IID. Assume vkâˆ¼ğ’©â€‹(Î¸,Ï„2)similar-tosubscriptğ‘£ğ‘˜ğ’©ğœƒsuperscriptğœ2v_{k}\sim\mathcal{N}(\theta,\tau^{2}), where Î¸ğœƒ\theta is drawn from the uniform uninformative prior on â„,â„\mathbb{R}, and Ï„ğœ\tau is a known constant. Here, Ï„ğœ\tau controls the degree of relatedness of the data on different devices: Ï„ğœ\tau=00 captures the case where the data on all devices are identically distributed while Ï„â†’âˆâ†’ğœ\tau\to\infty results in the scenario where the data on different devices are completely unrelated. The local objective is minvkâ¡Fkâ€‹(vk)=12â€‹(vkâˆ’1nkâ€‹âˆ‘i=1nkxk,i)2subscriptsubscriptğ‘£ğ‘˜subscriptğ¹ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘£ğ‘˜12superscriptsubscriptğ‘£ğ‘˜1subscriptğ‘›ğ‘˜superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1subscriptğ‘›ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜ğ‘–2\min_{v_{k}}F_{k}(v_{k})=\frac{1}{2}(v_{k}-\frac{1}{n_{k}}\sum_{i=1}^{n_{k}}x_{k,i})^{2}. In the presence of adversaries, we look at a specific type of label poisoning attack. Let Kasubscriptğ¾ğ‘K_{a} denote the number of malicious devices, and the â€˜capabilityâ€™ of an adversary is modeled by Ï„asubscriptğœğ‘\tau_{a}, i.e., the underlying model of an adversary follows ğ’©â€‹(Î¸,Ï„a2)ğ’©ğœƒsuperscriptsubscriptğœğ‘2\mathcal{N}(\theta,\tau_{a}^{2}) where Ï„a2>Ï„2superscriptsubscriptğœğ‘2superscriptğœ2\tau_{a}^{2}>\tau^{2}.

We first derive the Bayes estimator (which will be the most accurate and robust) for the real model distribution by observing a finite number of training points. Then, we show that by solving Ditto, we are able to recover the Bayes estimator with a proper Î»âˆ—superscriptğœ†\lambda^{*} (with the knowledge of Ï„ğœ\tau). In addition, the same Î»âˆ—superscriptğœ†\lambda^{*} results in the most fair solution among the set of solutions of Ditto parameterized by Î»ğœ†\lambda. This shows that Ditto with a proper choice of Î»ğœ†\lambda is Bayes optimal for this particular problem instance. In general, in TheoremÂ 8 (appendix), we prove that

Î»âˆ—=Ïƒ2nâ€‹KKâ€‹Ï„2+KaKâˆ’1â€‹(Ï„a2âˆ’Ï„2).superscriptğœ†superscriptğœ2ğ‘›ğ¾ğ¾superscriptğœ2subscriptğ¾ğ‘ğ¾1superscriptsubscriptğœğ‘2superscriptğœ2\displaystyle\lambda^{*}=\frac{\sigma^{2}}{n}\frac{K}{K\tau^{2}+\frac{K_{a}}{K-1}(\tau_{a}^{2}-\tau^{2})}.

We see that Î»âˆ—superscriptğœ†\lambda^{*} decreases when (i) there are more local samples nğ‘›n, (ii) the devices are less related (larger Ï„ğœ\tau), or (iii) the attacks are stronger (larger number of attackers, Ka,subscriptğ¾ğ‘K_{a}, and more powerful adversaries, Ï„asubscriptğœğ‘\tau_{a}). Related theorems (TheoremÂ 6-9) are presented in AppendixÂ A.3.

In FigureÂ 1, we plot average test error, fairness (standard deviation shown as error bars), and robustness (test error in the adversarial case) across a set of Î»ğœ†\lambdaâ€™s for both clean and adversarial cases. We see that in the solution space of Ditto, there exists a specific Î»ğœ†\lambda which minimizes the average test error and standard deviation across all devices at the same time, which is equal to the optimal Î»âˆ—superscriptğœ†\lambda^{*} given by our theory. FigureÂ 2 shows (i) Ditto with Î»âˆ—superscriptğœ†\lambda^{*} is superior than learning local or global models, and (ii) Î»âˆ—superscriptğœ†\lambda^{*} should increase as the relatedness between devices (1/Ï„1ğœ1/\tau) increases.

Linear Regression.

All results discussed above can be generalized to establish the optimality of Ditto on a class of linear regression problems (with additional assumptions on feature covariance). We defer readers to AppendixÂ A.2 for full statements and proofs. While our analyses here are limited to a simplified set of attacks and problem settings, we build on this intuition in SectionÂ 4â€”empirically demonstrating the accuracy, robustness, and fairness benefits of Ditto using both convex and non-convex models, across a range of federated learning benchmarks, and under a diverse set of attacks.

4 Experiments

In this section, we first demonstrate that Ditto can inherently offer similar or superior robustness relative to strong robust baselines (SectionÂ 4.1). We then show it results more fair performance than recent fair methods (SectionÂ 4.2). Ditto is particularly well-suited for mitigating the tension between these constraints and achieving both fairness and robustness simultaneously (SectionÂ 4.3). We explore additional beneficial properties of Ditto in SectionÂ 4.4.

Setup.

For all experiments, we measure robustness via test accuracy, and fairness via test accuracy variance (or standard deviation), both across benign devices (see Def.Â 1,Â 2). We use datasets from common FL benchmarksÂ (Caldas etÂ al., 2018; Smith etÂ al., 2017; TFF, ), which cover both vision and language tasks, and convex and non-convex models. Detailed datasets and models are provided in TableÂ 4 in AppendixÂ C. We split local data on each device into train/test/validation sets randomly, and measure performance on the test data. For each device, we select Î»ğœ†\lambda locally based on its local validation data. We further assume the devices can make a binary decision on whether the attack is strong or not. For devices with very few validation samples (less than 4), we use a fixed small Î»ğœ†\lambda (Î»ğœ†\lambda=0.1) for strong attacks, and use a fixed relatively large Î»ğœ†\lambda (Î»ğœ†\lambda=1) for all other attacks. For devices with more than 5 validation data points, we let each select Î»ğœ†\lambda from {0.05,0.1,0.2}0.050.10.2\{0.05,0.1,0.2\} for strong attacks, and select Î»ğœ†\lambda from {0.1,1,2}0.112\{0.1,1,2\} for all other attacks. See AppendixÂ D.2 for details. More advanced tuning methods are left for future work. Our code, data, and experiments are publicly available at github.com/litian96/ditto.

4.1 Robustness of Ditto

Following our threat model described in DefinitionÂ 1, we apply three attacks to corrupt a random subset of devices. We pick corruption levels until a point where there is a significant performance drop when training a global model. We compare robustness (Def.Â 1) of Ditto with various defense baselines, presenting the results of three strongest defenses in FigureÂ 3. Execution details and full results are reported in AppendixÂ D.4. As shown in FigureÂ 3, Ditto achieves the highest accuracy under most attacks, particularly those with a large fraction of malicious devices. On average across all datasets and attacks, Ditto results in âˆ¼similar-to\sim6% absolute accuracy improvement compared with the strongest robust baseline (AppendixÂ D.4). In scenarios where a robust baseline outperforms Ditto, we have also found that replacing the global objective and its solver (FedAvg) with a robust version (e.g., using robust aggregators) can further improve Ditto, yielding superior performance (SectionÂ 4.4).

4.2 Fairness of Ditto

To explore the fairness of Ditto, we compare against TERMÂ (Li etÂ al., 2021) as a baseline. It is an improved version of the qğ‘q-FFLÂ (Li etÂ al., 2020e) objective, which has been recently proposed for fair federated learning. TERM also recovers AFLÂ (Mohri etÂ al., 2019), another fair FL objective, as a special case. TERM uses a parameter tğ‘¡t to offer flexible tradeoffs between fairness and accuracy. In TableÂ 1, we compare the proposed objective with global, local, and fair methods (TERM) in terms of test accuracies and standard deviation. When the corruption level is high, â€˜globalâ€™ or â€˜fairâ€™ will even fail to converge. Ditto results in more accurate and fair solutions both with and without attacks. On average across all datasets, Ditto reduces variance across devices by âˆ¼similar-to\sim10% while improving absolute test accuracy by 5%percent55\% compared with TERM (on clean data).

4.3 Addressing Competing Constraints

In this section, we examine the competing constraints between robustness and fairness. When training a single global model, fair methods aim to encourage a more uniform performance distribution, but may be highly susceptible to training-time attacks in statistically heterogeneous environments. We investigate the test accuracy on benign devices when learning global, local, and fair models. In the TERM objective, we set t=1,2,5ğ‘¡125t=1,2,5 to achieve different levels of fairness (the higher, the fairer). We perform the data poisoning attack (A1 in Def.Â 1). The results are plotted in FigureÂ 4. As the corruption level increases, we see that fitting a global model becomes less robust. Using fair methods will be more susceptible to attacks. When tğ‘¡t gets larger, the test accuracy gets lower, an indication that the fair method is overfitting to the corrupted devices relative to the global baseline.

Next, we apply various strong robust methods under the same attack, and explore the robustness/accuracy and fairness performance. The robust approaches include: Krum, multi-KrumÂ (Blanchard etÂ al., 2017), taking the coordinate-wise median of gradients (â€˜medianâ€™), gradient clipping (â€˜clippingâ€™), filtering out the gradients with largest norms (â€˜k-normâ€™), and taking the gradient of the kğ‘˜k-th largest loss where kğ‘˜k is the number of malicious devices (â€˜k-lossâ€™). For Krum, multi-Krum, kğ‘˜k-norm, and kğ‘˜k-loss, we assume that the server knows the expected number of malicious devices that are selected each round, and can set kğ‘˜k accordingly for kğ‘˜k-norm and kğ‘˜k-loss. From FigureÂ 5, we see that robust baselines are either (i) more robust than global but less fair, or (ii) fail to provide robustness due to heterogeneity. Ditto is more robust, accurate, and fair.

4.4 Additional Properties of Ditto

Personalization.

We additionally explore the performance of other personalized FL methods in terms of accuracy and fairness, on both clean and adversarial cases. In particular, we consider objectives that (i) regularize with the average (L2SGDÂ (Hanzely & RichtÃ¡rik, 2020)) or the learnt device relationship matrix (MOCHAÂ (Smith etÂ al., 2017)), (ii) encourage closeness to the global model in terms of some specific function behavior (EWCÂ (Kirkpatrick etÂ al., 2017; Yu etÂ al., 2020) and Symmetrized KL (SKL)), (iii) interpolate between local and global models (APFLÂ (Deng etÂ al., 2021) and mapperÂ (Mansour etÂ al., 2020)), and (iv) have been motivated by meta-learning (Per-FedAvg (HF)Â (Fallah etÂ al., 2020)). We provide a detailed description in AppendixÂ C.

We compare Ditto with the above alternatives, using the same learning rate tuned on FedAvg on clean data for all methods except Per-FedAvg, which requires additional tuning to prevent divergence. For finetuning methods (EWC and SKL), we finetune on each local device for 50 epochs starting from the converged global model. We report results of baseline methods using their best hyperparameters. Despite Dittoâ€™s simplicity, in TableÂ 2 below, we see that Ditto achieves similar or superier test accuracy with slightly lower standard deviation compared with these recent personalization methods.

We also evaluate the performance of MOCHA with a convex SVM model in TableÂ 7 in the appendix. MOCHA is more robust and fair than most baselines, which is in line with our reasoning that personalization can provide benefits for these constraints. Further understanding the robustness/fairness benefits of other personalized approaches would be an interesting direction of future work.

Augmenting with Robust Baselines.

Ditto allows the flexibility of learning robust wâˆ—superscriptğ‘¤w^{*} leveraging any previous robust aggregation techniques, which could further improve the performance of personalized models. For instance, in the aggregation step at the server side (Line 7 in AlgorithmÂ 1), instead of simply averaging the global model updates as in FedAvg, we can aggregate them via multi-Krum, or after gradient clipping. As is shown in TableÂ 3, Ditto combined with clipping yields improvements compared with vanilla Ditto. We present full results on different datasets trying varying robust methods in TableÂ 6 in the appendix.

Comparing Two Solvers.

As mentioned in SectionÂ 3.2, another way to solve Ditto is to finetune on minvkâ¡hkâ€‹(vk;wâˆ—)subscriptsubscriptğ‘£ğ‘˜subscriptâ„ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘£ğ‘˜superscriptğ‘¤\min_{v_{k}}h_{k}(v_{k};w^{*}) for each kâˆˆ[K]ğ‘˜delimited-[]ğ¾k\in[K] after obtaining wâˆ—superscriptğ‘¤w^{*}. We examine the performance of two solvers under the model replacement attack (A3) with 20% adversaries. In realistic federated networks, it may be challenging to determine how many iterations to finetune for, particularly over a heterogeneous network of devices. To obtain the best performance of finetuning, we solve minvkâ¡hkâ€‹(vk;wâˆ—)subscriptsubscriptğ‘£ğ‘˜subscriptâ„ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘£ğ‘˜superscriptğ‘¤\min_{v_{k}}h_{k}(v_{k};w^{*}) on each device by running different iterations of mini-batch SGD and pick the best one. As shown in FigureÂ 6, the finetuning solver improves the performance compared with learning a global model, whileÂ Ditto combined with joint optimization performs the best. One can also perform finetuning after early stopping; however, it is essentially solving a different objective and it is difficult to determine the stopping criteria. We discuss this in more detail in AppendixÂ D.1.

5 Conclusion and Future Work

We propose Ditto, a simple MTL framework, to address the competing constraints of accuracy, fairness, and robustness in federated learning. Ditto can be thought of as a lightweight personalization add-on for any global federated objective, which maintains the privacy and communication efficiency of the global solver. We theoretically analyze the ability of Ditto to mitigate the tension between fairness and robustness on a class of linear problems. Our empirical results demonstrate that Ditto can result in both more robust and fairer models compared with strong baselines across a diverse set of attacks. Our work suggests several interesting directions of future study, such as exploring the applicability of Ditto to other attacks such as backdoor attacksÂ (e.g., Sun etÂ al., 2019); understanding the fairness/robustness properties of other personalized methods; and considering additional constraints, such as privacy.

Appendix A Analysis of the Federated Multi-Task Learning Objective Ditto

Here, we provide theoretical analyses of Ditto, mainly on a class of linear models. In this linear setting, we investigate accuracy, fairness, and robustness of Ditto. We first discuss some general properties of Ditto for strongly convex functions in terms of the training performance in SectionÂ A.1. We next present our main results on characterizing the benefits (accuracy, fairness, and robustness) of Ditto on linear regression in SectionÂ A.2. Finally, we present results on a special case of linear regression (federated point estimation problem examined in SectionÂ 3.3) in SectionÂ A.3.

A.1 Properties of Ditto for Strongly Convex Functions

As Î»ğœ†\lambda increases, the local empirical training loss Fkâ€‹(w^kâ€‹(Î»))subscriptğ¹ğ‘˜subscript^ğ‘¤ğ‘˜ğœ†F_{k}(\widehat{w}_{k}(\lambda)) will also increase, and the resulting personalized models will be closer to the global model. Since for any device kâˆˆ[K]ğ‘˜delimited-[]ğ¾k\in[K], training loss is minimized when Î»=0ğœ†0\lambda=0, training separate local models is the most robust and fair in terms of training performance when we do not consider generalization.

However, in order to obtain the guarantees on the test performance, we need to explicitly model the joint distribution of data on all devices. In the next section, we explore a Bayesian framework on a class of linear problems to examine the generalization, fairness, and robustness of the Ditto objective, all on the underlying test data.

A.2 Federated Linear Regression

We first examine the case without corrupted devices in SectionÂ A.2.1. We prove that there exists a Î»ğœ†\lambda that results in an optimal average test performance among all possible federated learning algorithms, which coincides with the optimal Î»ğœ†\lambda in Dittoâ€™s solution space in terms of fairness. When there are adversaries, we analyze the robustness benefits of Ditto in SectionÂ A.2.2. In particular, we show there exists a Î»ğœ†\lambda which leads to the highest test accuracy across benign devices (i.e., the most robust) and minimizes the variance of the test error across benign devices (i.e., the most fair) jointly.

Before we proceed, we first state a technical lemma that will be used throughout the analyses.

Remark 1.

We note that by using Î»âˆ—superscriptğœ†\lambda^{*} in Ditto, we not only achieve the most accurate solution for the objective, but also we achieve the most accurate solution of any possible federated linear regression algorithm in this problem, as Ditto with Î»âˆ—superscriptğœ†\lambda^{*} realizes the MMSE estimator for wksubscriptğ‘¤ğ‘˜w_{k}.

We have derived an optimal Î»âˆ—=Ïƒ2nâ€‹Ï„2superscriptğœ†superscriptğœ2ğ‘›superscriptğœ2\lambda^{*}=\frac{\sigma^{2}}{n\tau^{2}} for Ditto in terms of generalization. Recall that we define fairness as the variance of the performance across all devicesÂ (Hashimoto etÂ al., 2018; Li etÂ al., 2020e). Next, we prove that the same Î»âˆ—superscriptğœ†\lambda^{*} that minimizes the expected MSE also achieves the optimal fairness among all Ditto solutions.

Observations.

From the optimal Î»âˆ—=Ïƒ2nâ€‹Ï„2superscriptğœ†superscriptğœ2ğ‘›superscriptğœ2\lambda^{*}=\frac{\sigma^{2}}{n\tau^{2}} for mean test accuracy and variance of the test accuracy, we have the following observations.

  • â€¢

    Test error and variance can be jointly minimized with one Î»ğœ†\lambda.

  • â€¢

    As nâ†’âˆ,â†’ğ‘›n\to\infty, Î»âˆ—â†’0,â†’superscriptğœ†0\lambda^{*}\to 0, i.e., when each local device has an infinite number of samples, there is no need for federated learning, and training local models is optimal in terms of generalization and fairness.

  • â€¢

    As Ï„â†’âˆ,â†’ğœ\tau\to\infty, Î»âˆ—â†’0,â†’superscriptğœ†0\lambda^{*}\to 0, i.e., if the data on different devices (the tasks) are unrelated, then training local models is optimal; On the other hand, as Ï„â†’0,â†’ğœ0\tau\to 0, Î»âˆ—â†’âˆ,â†’superscriptğœ†\lambda^{*}\to\infty, i.e., if the data across all devices are identically distributed, or equivalently if the tasks are the same, then training a global model is the best we can achieve.

So far we have proved that the same Î»âˆ—superscriptğœ†\lambda^{*} achieves the best performance (expected mean square error) for any device kğ‘˜k and fairness (variance of mean square error) without considering adversaries. In SectionÂ A.2.2 below, we analyze the benefits of Ditto for fairness and robustness in the presence of adversaries.

A.2.2 With Adversaries: Ditto for Accuracy, Fairness, and Robustness

Observations.

From Î»aâˆ—superscriptsubscriptğœ†ğ‘\lambda_{a}^{*}, we have the following interesting observations.

  • â€¢

    Mean test error on benign devices (robustness) and variance of the performance across benign devices (fairness) can still be minimized with the same Î»asubscriptğœ†ğ‘\lambda_{a} in the presence of adversaries.

  • â€¢

    As Ï„aâ†’âˆâ†’subscriptğœğ‘\tau_{a}\to\infty, Î»aâˆ—â†’0,â†’subscriptsuperscriptğœ†ğ‘0\lambda^{*}_{a}\to 0, i.e., training local models is optimal in terms of robustness and fairness when adversaryâ€™s task may be arbitrarily far from the the task in the benign devices.

  • â€¢

    As Ï„â†’0â†’ğœ0\tau\to 0, if Ï„a>0subscriptğœğ‘0\tau_{a}>0, Î»aâˆ—<âˆsubscriptsuperscriptğœ†ğ‘\lambda^{*}_{a}<\infty, which means that learning a global model is not optimal even with homogeneous data in the presence of adversaries.

  • â€¢

    Î»aâˆ—subscriptsuperscriptğœ†ğ‘\lambda^{*}_{a} is a decreasing function of the number (Kasubscriptğ¾ğ‘K_{a}) and the capability (Ï„asubscriptğœğ‘\tau_{a}) of the corrupted devices. In other words, as the attacks become more adversarial, we need more personalization.

  • â€¢

    The smallest test error is Ïƒw,a2subscriptsuperscriptğœ2ğ‘¤ğ‘\sigma^{2}_{w,a}, and the optimal variance is 2â€‹Ïƒw,a42subscriptsuperscriptğœ4ğ‘¤ğ‘2\sigma^{4}_{w,a}, which are both increasing with Kasubscriptğ¾ğ‘K_{a} (number of adversarial devices) or Ï„asubscriptğœğ‘\tau_{a} (the power of adversary) by inspectingÂ (59) andÂ (60). This reveals a fundamental tradeoff between fairness and robustness.

Discussion.

Through our analysis, we prove that Ditto with an appropriate Î»ğœ†\lambda is more accurate, robust, and fair compared with training global or local models on the problem described inÂ A.2. We provide closed-form solutions for Î»âˆ—superscriptğœ†\lambda^{*} across different settings (with and without adversaries), and show that Ditto can achieve fairness and robustness jointly. In the future, we plan to generalize the current theoretical framework to more general models. In the next section, we present a special case of the current analysis, a federated point estimation problem, which is also studied in SectionÂ 3.3 as a motivating example.

Appendix B Algorithm and Convergence Analysis

In this section, we first present the specific algorithm (AlgorithmÂ 2) that we use for most of our experiments (all except for TableÂ 3 andÂ 6). Discussions.

TheoremÂ 10 also suggests how the percentage/power of malicious devices can affect convergence rates. The percentage/power of adversaries impacts both the optimal global solution wâˆ—superscriptğ‘¤w^{*}, and the convergence rate of the global model gâ€‹(t)ğ‘”ğ‘¡g(t). (i) For wâˆ—superscriptğ‘¤w^{*}, it affects Mğ‘€M in EqÂ (91)â€”the distance between the local model on a benign device and the global model. This in turn affects Î»ğœ†\lambda in EqÂ (95) andÂ (107), and the constant Cğ¶C. Î»ğœ†\lambda can scale inversely proportional to Mğ‘€M, which is consistent with our fairness/robustness analysis where Î»âˆ—superscriptğœ†\lambda^{*} should decrease as the increase of Ï„2superscriptğœ2\tau^{2}. (ii) For gâ€‹(t)ğ‘”ğ‘¡g(t), the modularity of Ditto allows for decoupling the convergence of personalized models and the global model (as demonstrated by this theorem), and we can plug in any previous algorithms and their analysis on the convergence rate gâ€‹(t)ğ‘”ğ‘¡g(t) as a function of malicious devices.

As a direct result of TheoremÂ 10, we could state a result for Ditto when the global objective is FedAvg.

Corollary 1 (Convergence of personalized models).

Under the assumptions above, if the global objective Gâ€‹(â‹…)ğºâ‹…G(\cdot) is FedAvg, then under AlgorithmÂ 2, for kâˆˆ[K]ğ‘˜delimited-[]ğ¾k\in[K],

ğ”¼â€‹[â€–vktâˆ’vkâˆ—â€–2]=Oâ€‹(1/t).ğ”¼delimited-[]superscriptnormsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘£ğ‘˜ğ‘¡superscriptsubscriptğ‘£ğ‘˜2ğ‘‚1ğ‘¡\displaystyle\mathbb{E}[\|v_{k}^{t}-v_{k}^{*}\|^{2}]=O(1/t). (112)
Proof.

FromÂ Li etÂ al. (2020f) Theorem 2, we know the global model for FedAvg converges at a rate of Oâ€‹(1/t)ğ‘‚1ğ‘¡O(1/t), i.e.,

ğ”¼â€‹[â€–wtâˆ’wâˆ—â€–2]â‰¤Dâ€²t+Bâ€‹â€–w1âˆ’wâˆ—â€–2â‰¤Dt+1,ğ”¼delimited-[]superscriptnormsuperscriptğ‘¤ğ‘¡superscriptğ‘¤2superscriptğ·â€²ğ‘¡ğµsuperscriptnormsuperscriptğ‘¤1superscriptğ‘¤2ğ·ğ‘¡1\displaystyle\mathbb{E}[\|w^{t}-w^{*}\|^{2}]\leq\frac{D^{\prime}}{t+B}\|w^{1}-w^{*}\|^{2}\leq\frac{D}{t+1}, (113)

where D,Dâ€²,Bğ·superscriptğ·â€²ğµD,D^{\prime},B are constants. Setting gâ€‹(t)=Dt+1ğ‘”ğ‘¡ğ·ğ‘¡1g(t)=\frac{D}{t+1} and A=Dğ´ğ·A=D in TheoremÂ 10, it follows that ğ”¼â€‹[â€–vktâˆ’vkâˆ—â€–2]=Oâ€‹(1/t)ğ”¼delimited-[]superscriptnormsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘£ğ‘˜ğ‘¡superscriptsubscriptğ‘£ğ‘˜2ğ‘‚1ğ‘¡\mathbb{E}[\|v_{k}^{t}-v_{k}^{*}\|^{2}]=O(1/t). âˆ

Appendix C Experimental Details

C.1 Datasets and Models

We summarize the datasets, corresponding models, and tasks in TableÂ 4 below. We evaluate the performance of Ditto with both convex and non-convex models across a set of FL benchmarks. In our datasets, we have both image data (FEMNIST, CelebA, Fashion MNIST), and text data (StackOverflow).

FEMNIST is Federated EMNIST, which is EMNISTÂ (Cohen etÂ al., 2017) partitioned by the writers of digits/characters created by a previous federated learning benchmarkÂ (Caldas etÂ al., 2018). We have two versions of FEMNIST in this work under different partitions with different levels of statistical heterogeneity. The manually-partitioned version is more heterogeneous than the naturally-partitioned one, as we assign 5 classes to each device. We show that the benefits of Ditto can be more significant on the skewed FEMNIST data (TableÂ 10). All results shown in the main text are based on the natural partition. We downsample the number of data points on each device (following the power law) for Vehicle. For FEMNIST, CelebA, and StackOverflow, we randomly sample devices (users) from the entire dataset. We use the full version of Fashion MNIST (which has been used in previous FL worksÂ (Bhagoji etÂ al., 2019)), and assign 5 classes to each device.

C.2 Personalization Baselines

We elaborate on the personalization baselines used in our experiments (TableÂ 2) which allow for partial device participation and local updating. We consider:

  • â€¢

    MOCHAÂ (Smith etÂ al., 2017), a primal-dual framework for multi-task learning. It jointly learns the model parameters and a device relation matrix, and applicable to convex problems.

  • â€¢

    APFLÂ (Deng etÂ al., 2021), which proposes to interpolate between local and global models for personalization. While it can reduce to solving local problems (without constraints on the solution space) as pointed out inÂ (Deng etÂ al., 2021), we find that in neural network applications, it has some personalization benefits, possibly due to the joint optimization solver.

  • â€¢

    Elastic Weight Consolidation (EWC), which takes into account the Fisher information when finetuning from the optimal global modelÂ (Kirkpatrick etÂ al., 2017; Yu etÂ al., 2020). The local objective is minwâ¡Fkâ€‹(w)+Î»2â€‹âˆ‘iğ…iâ€‹iâ‹…(wâ€‹[i]âˆ’wâˆ—â€‹[i])2subscriptğ‘¤subscriptğ¹ğ‘˜ğ‘¤ğœ†2subscriptğ‘–â‹…subscriptğ…ğ‘–ğ‘–superscriptğ‘¤delimited-[]ğ‘–superscriptğ‘¤delimited-[]ğ‘–2\min_{w}F_{k}(w)+\frac{\lambda}{2}\sum_{i}\mathbf{F}_{ii}\cdot(w[i]-w^{*}[i])^{2} where [i]delimited-[]ğ‘–[i] denotes the index of parameters and ğ…iâ€‹isubscriptğ…ğ‘–ğ‘–\mathbf{F}_{ii} denotes the iğ‘–i-th diagonal of the empirical Fisher matrix ğ…ğ…\mathbf{F} estimated using a data batch.

  • â€¢

    L2SGD, which regularizes personalized models towards their meanÂ (Hanzely & RichtÃ¡rik, 2020). The proposed method requires full device participation once in a while. However, to remain consistent with the other solvers, we use their objective but adopt a different solver with partial device participationâ€”each selected local device solving minwâ¡Fkâ€‹(w)+Î»2â€‹â€–wâˆ’wÂ¯â€–2subscriptğ‘¤subscriptğ¹ğ‘˜ğ‘¤ğœ†2superscriptnormğ‘¤Â¯ğ‘¤2\min_{w}F_{k}(w)+\frac{\lambda}{2}\|w-\bar{w}\|^{2} where wÂ¯Â¯ğ‘¤\bar{w} is the current mean of all personalized models wÂ¯=1Nâ€‹âˆ‘k=1NwkÂ¯ğ‘¤1ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘˜1ğ‘subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘˜\bar{w}=\frac{1}{N}\sum_{k=1}^{N}w_{k}.

    Mapper, which is one of the three personalization methods proposed inÂ Mansour etÂ al. (2020) that needs the minimal amount of meta-information. Similar to APFL, it is also motivated by model interpolation.

  • â€¢

    Per-FedAvg (HF)Â (Fallah etÂ al., 2020) which applies MAMLÂ (Finn etÂ al., 2017) to personalize federated models with an Hessian-product approximation to approximate the second-order gradients.

Appendix D Additional and Complete Experiment Results

D.1 Comparing with Finetuning

As discussed in SectionÂ 3.2, finetuning on hksubscriptâ„ğ‘˜h_{k} for each device kğ‘˜k is a possible solver for Ditto. In non-convex cases, however, starting from a corrupted wâˆ—superscriptğ‘¤w^{*} may result in inferior performance compared with AlgorithmÂ 1. We provide a simple example to illustrate this point. To perform finetuning, we run different numbers of epochs of mini-batch SGD on the Ditto objective for each device in the network, and pick the best one. As shown in FigureÂ 7 below, finetuning at round 5,000 will not result in a good final accuracy. We observe that one could also stop at early iterations and then finetune. However, it is difficult to do so in practice based on the training or validation data alone, as shown in FigureÂ 8.

D.2 Tuning Î»ğœ†\lambda

We assume that the server does not have knowledge of which devices are benign vs. malicious, and we have each device locally select and apply a best Î»ğœ†\lambda from a candidate set of three values based on their validation data. For benign devices, this means they will pick a Î»ğœ†\lambda based on their clean validation signal. For malicious devices, how they perform personalization (i.e., selecting Î»ğœ†\lambda) does not affect the corrupted global model updates they send, which are independent of Î»ğœ†\lambda. We further assume the devices have some knowledge of how â€˜strongâ€™ the attack is. We define strong attacks as (i) all of model replacement attacks (A3) where the magnitude of the model updates from malicious devices can scale by >10Ã—>10\times, and (ii) other attacks where more than half of the devices are corrupted. In particular, for devices with very few validation samples (less than 4), we use a fixed small Î»ğœ†\lambda (Î»ğœ†\lambda=0.1) for strong attacks, and use a fixed relatively large Î»ğœ†\lambda (Î»ğœ†\lambda=1) for all other attacks. For devices with more than 5 validation data points, we let each select Î»ğœ†\lambda from {0.05,0.1,0.2}0.050.10.2\{0.05,0.1,0.2\} for strong attacks, and select Î»ğœ†\lambda from {0.1,1,2}0.112\{0.1,1,2\} for all other attacks. For the StackOverflow dataset, we tune Î»ğœ†\lambda from {0.01,0.05,0.1}0.010.050.1\{0.01,0.05,0.1\} for strong attacks, and {0.05,0.1,0.3}0.050.10.3\{0.05,0.1,0.3\} for all other attacks. We directly evaluate our hyperparameter tuning strategy in TableÂ 5 belowâ€”showing that this dynamic tuning heuristic works well relative to an ideal, but more unrealistic strategy that picks the best Î»ğœ†\lambda based on knowledge of which devices are benign vs. malicious (i.e., by only using the validation data of the benign devices).

D.3 Ditto Augmented with Robust Baselines

In SectionÂ 4.4, we demonstrate that the performance of Ditto can be further improved when it is combined with robust baselines (e.g., learning a robust wâˆ—superscriptğ‘¤w^{*} via robust aggregation). Here, we report full results validating this claim in TableÂ 6 below.

D.4 Ditto Complete Results

In SectionÂ 4.1, we present partial results on three strong attacks on two datasets. Here, we provide full results showing the robustness and fairness of Ditto on all attacks and all datasets compared with all defense baselines. We randomly split local data on each device into 72% train, 8% validation, and 20% test sets, and report all results on test data. We use a learning rate of 0.01 for StackOverflow, 0.05 for Fashion MNIST and 0.1 for all other datasets; and batch size 16 for CelebA and Fashion MNIST, 32 for FEMNIST and Vehicle, and 100 for StackOverflow. For every dataset, we first run FedAvg on clean data to determine the number of communication rounds. Then we run the same number of rounds for all attacks on that dataset.

For our robust baselines, â€˜medianâ€™ means coordinate-wise median. For Krum, multi-Krum, kğ‘˜k-norm, and kğ‘˜k-loss, we assume the server knows the expected number of malicious devices when aggregation. In other words, for kğ‘˜k-norm, we filter out the updates with the kğ‘˜k largest norms where kğ‘˜k is set to the expected number of malicious devices. Similarly, for kğ‘˜k-loss, we only use the model update with the kğ‘˜k+111-th largest training loss. For gradient clipping, we set the threshold to be the median of the gradient norms coming from all selected devices at each round. FedMGDA+ has an additional Îµğœ€\varepsilon hyperparameter which we select from {0,0.1,0.5,1}00.10.51\{0,0.1,0.5,1\} based on the validation performance on benign devices. For the finetuning (only on neural network models) baseline, we run 50 epochs of mini-batch SGD on each device on the local objective Fksubscriptğ¹ğ‘˜F_{k} starting from wâˆ—superscriptğ‘¤w^{*}. We see that Ditto can achieve better fairness and robustness in most cases. In particular, on average of all datasets and all attack scenarios, Ditto (with dynamic Î»ğœ†\lambdaâ€™s) achieves Â 6% absolute accuracy improvement compared with the strongest robust baseline. In terms of fairness, Ditto is able to reduce the variance of test accuracy by 10%percent1010\% while improving the average accuracy by 5% relative to state-of-the-art methods for fair FL (without attacks).
